name: Display PCI Device Information
helpContent:
To display a list of PCI devices recognized by the Linux kernel, use the lspci command.

This command provides information such as PCI device bus, device, and function numbers.
tutorial:
$ lspci

00:00.0 Host bridge: Intel Corporation 440FX - 82441FX PMC [Natoma] (rev 02)

name: Display PCI Device Information (Tree Format)
helpContent:
Use the lspci -t command to display PCI device information in tree format.

This provides a clear hierarchical view of the devices.

name: Display USB Device Information
helpContent:
The lsusb command displays information about USB devices.

It shows a detailed list of connected USB devices.

name: Display CPU Information
helpContent:
The cat /proc/cpuinfo command displays detailed information about the CPU in your PC.

This includes processor model, clock speed, number of cores, and more.

name: Display Memory Information
helpContent:
The cat /proc/meminfo command displays information about the memory in your PC.

Detailed statistics about physical and swap memory are shown.

name: Display System Architecture
helpContent:
Use the arch command to display the system's architecture (32-bit or 64-bit).

If run without options, it shows the default architecture of the system.

name: Display 32-bit Architecture
helpContent:
Use the arch -i386 command to display information about the 32-bit architecture.

This is an example with the specified option.

name: Display Distribution Information
helpContent:
The cat /etc/os-release command displays detailed information about the current Linux distribution.

It includes the distribution's name, version, ID, and more.

name: Display Linux Kernel Version
helpContent:
Use the uname -r command to display the Linux kernel version.

This command is commonly used to check the system's kernel version.

name: Display System Details
helpContent:
The uname -a command displays detailed information about the system.

This includes the kernel version, hostname, architecture, and more.
